unit_title: Acceleration: The Rate of Change of Velocity
subject: Physics
expanded_description: Understand acceleration as the rate at which velocity changes. Learn to calculate acceleration, distinguish between positive and negative acceleration (deceleration), apply the equations of motion, and analyze acceleration in various contexts including free fall and circular motion.

core_concept.principle: Acceleration: The rate of change of velocity with time
core_concept.explanation: Acceleration measures how quickly velocity changes - either in magnitude (speed) or direction. It is a vector quantity that can be positive (speeding up), negative (slowing down), or zero (constant velocity).

image.alt: Car speeding up showing acceleration in direction of motion, car slowing down showing acceleration opposite motion, car turning showing acceleration perpendicular to motion
image.caption: Acceleration can change speed, direction, or both - it's not just about getting faster

sections.introduction: Acceleration describes how velocity changes over time. Unlike velocity which tells us how position changes, acceleration tells us how velocity itself changes - making it the 'rate of change of a rate of change'.

key_concept.definition: Acceleration = change in velocity / time interval | a = (v - u)/t
key_concept.context: Acceleration occurs whenever there is a change in speed, direction, or both. Even constant speed motion can have acceleration if direction changes.

categories.description: Acceleration has both magnitude and direction like all vectors
categories.detailed_mechanism: The direction of acceleration determines whether an object speeds up, slows down, or changes direction.

examples.explanation: Acceleration in same direction as velocity - object speeds up
Acceleration opposite to velocity - object slows down
Acceleration perpendicular to velocity - object changes direction but not speed

categories.description: How acceleration is measured and expressed

examples.explanation: m/s² (meters per second squared) - velocity change in m/s per second
9.8 m/s² means velocity increases by 9.8 m/s each second
km/h/s, ft/s² - less common but sometimes used

sections.introduction: Acceleration is calculated using the basic definition formula. The sign and magnitude provide important information about how the motion is changing.

key_concept.definition: Average Acceleration = (final velocity - initial velocity) / time | a_avg = (v - u)/t
key_concept.context: This formula gives the average acceleration over a time interval. Instantaneous acceleration would be the limit as the time interval approaches zero.

process_flow.description: Determine initial velocity (u) and final velocity (v) with signs for direction
process_flow.result: Example: u = 20 m/s, v = 30 m/s (both positive = same direction)

process_flow.description: Find the time (t) over which the velocity change occurred
Use a = (v - u)/t with proper signs
Positive acceleration = speeding up, Negative = slowing down
process_flow.result: +2 m/s² = acceleration in direction of motion (speeding up)

sections.introduction: The sign of acceleration relative to velocity determines whether an object is speeding up or slowing down. This relationship is crucial for understanding motion.

key_concept.definition: Acceleration and velocity same sign = speeding up | Acceleration and velocity opposite signs = slowing down
key_concept.context: Negative acceleration doesn't necessarily mean moving backward - it means slowing down in whatever direction you're moving.

principles.statement: When acceleration and velocity have the same direction
principles.application: Object gains speed in its current direction of motion
principles.example: Car moving East at 20 m/s, acceleration 2 m/s² East → speeding up East

principles.statement: When acceleration and velocity have opposite directions
principles.application: Object loses speed in its current direction of motion
principles.example: Car moving East at 20 m/s, acceleration 3 m/s² West → slowing down East

examples.explanation: Common term for negative acceleration (slowing down)
Alternative term used in some contexts
Most precise physics term
+ velocity, + acceleration = speeding up forward
+ velocity, - acceleration = slowing down forward
- velocity, - acceleration = speeding up backward
- velocity, + acceleration = slowing down backward

sections.introduction: The equations of motion (kinematic equations) describe relationships between displacement, velocity, acceleration, and time for objects moving with constant acceleration.

key_concept.definition: Four key equations connect the five motion variables: u, v, a, s, t
key_concept.context: These equations only work when acceleration is constant. They are fundamental tools for solving motion problems.

principles.application: Find final velocity given initial velocity, acceleration, and time
Find displacement given initial velocity, acceleration, and time
Find final velocity given initial velocity, acceleration, and displacement
Find displacement using average velocity and time

sections.introduction: Gravity causes all objects near Earth's surface to accelerate downward at approximately 9.8 m/s², regardless of their mass. This fundamental acceleration appears in many physics problems.

key_concept.definition: g = 9.8 m/s² downward (approximately) - acceleration due to gravity
key_concept.context: This value varies slightly with location and altitude, but 9.8 m/s² is used for most calculations.

principles.statement: All objects in free fall accelerate at g downward (ignoring air resistance)
principles.application: Use a = -9.8 m/s² (if up is positive) for falling objects
principles.example: Dropped stone: u = 0, a = -9.8 m/s², accelerates downward

principles.statement: Velocity is zero but acceleration is still g downward
principles.application: Even when momentarily stopped at the top of its path, acceleration continues
principles.example: Ball thrown upward: at highest point, v = 0 but a = -9.8 m/s²

examples.explanation: u = 0, a = -9.8 m/s²: v = -gt, s = -½gt²
u = +, a = -9.8 m/s²: slows to stop at top, then falls
Use equations to find time to fall, time to peak height, etc.

sections.introduction: Even when speed is constant, an object moving in a circle experiences acceleration because its direction constantly changes. This centripetal acceleration points toward the circle's center.

key_concept.definition: Centripetal Acceleration: Acceleration toward the center of circular path
key_concept.context: This acceleration changes the direction of velocity but not its magnitude, keeping the object moving in a circle.

principles.statement: Always points toward the center of the circular path
principles.application: Perpendicular to velocity vector at each point
principles.example: Car turning: acceleration toward center of turn, not in direction of travel

principles.statement: Circular motion can have constant speed but changing velocity
principles.application: Velocity changes because direction changes → acceleration exists
principles.example: Satellite in orbit: constant speed but acceleration toward Earth

categories.description: Key ideas about acceleration in circular paths

examples.explanation: The feeling of being pushed outward is actually inertia, not a real force
Any curved motion requires centripetal acceleration toward center of curvature
Perfect example of constant speed but changing velocity

sections.introduction: Acceleration can itself be constant or changing. The equations of motion only apply when acceleration is constant.

key_concept.definition: Constant Acceleration: Same magnitude and direction over time | Changing Acceleration: Magnitude or direction changes over time
key_concept.context: Most introductory problems assume constant acceleration because the mathematics is simpler and the equations of motion apply.

principles.statement: Equations of motion require acceleration to be constant
principles.application: Check if acceleration changes before using v = u + at, etc.
principles.example: Free fall near Earth's surface: approximately constant acceleration

principles.statement: More complex motion requires calculus methods
principles.application: When acceleration varies, use integration methods
principles.example: Rocket launch: acceleration increases as fuel burns and mass decreases

summary: Acceleration is the rate of change of velocity with time, measured in m/s². It is a vector quantity that can be positive (speeding up), negative (slowing down/deceleration), or zero (constant velocity). The equations of motion (v = u + at, s = ut + ½at², v² = u² + 2as, s = ½(u + v)t) describe relationships between displacement, velocity, acceleration, and time for constant acceleration. Gravity causes approximately 9.8 m/s² downward acceleration near Earth's surface. Circular motion involves centripetal acceleration toward the center, changing direction but not speed. Understanding acceleration is crucial for analyzing motion in transportation, sports, and natural phenomena. Common mistakes include sign confusion, gravity direction errors, and misapplying equations to non-constant acceleration situations.
